p:
During the initial rapid spread of WNV in the US, the lack of geographic structure (i.e., “bush-like’ tree topology;
S2 Fig ) detected from the numerous national [ 24, 26, 51– 54] and regional [ 51, 55– 58] phylogenetic studies suggests that WNV encountered a highly conducive environment with few barriers after it was introduced. This is likely due in part to the large diversity of hosts and vectors that WNV can utilize for transmission [ 1– 3]. Among these, highly abundant passerine birds (e.g., thrushes and sparrows) [ 59] and Culex mosquitoes (e.g., C. tarsalis and C. pipiens) [ 60– 62] are the most important for maintaining WNV transmission. Therefore, it is likely that a large population of susceptible hosts and vectors already present in the Americas helped WNV to quickly conquer a continent despite the varied landscapes that it needed to traverse.
